article_title: Hubble, Euclid, and Subaru Discover a Galaxy That Is 99% Dark Matter—Detected Only by Its Globular Clusters

content_preview.title: Hubble, Euclid, and Subaru Discover a Galaxy That Is 99% Dark Matter—Detected Only by Its Globular Clusters
content_preview.summary: CDG-2, a near-invisible galaxy 300 million light-years away, is the first detected solely through its globular cluster population. Roughly 99% of its mass is dark matter.
content_preview.body_excerpt:
## Overview

A team led by David Li at the University of Toronto has identified one of the most extreme galaxies ever found. Designated CDG-2 (Candidate Dark Galaxy-2), it sits roughly 300 million light-years away within the Perseus galaxy cluster and appears to consist of approximately 99% dark matter—making it nearly undetectable by conventional observation. editor_notes.factual_accuracy: Core scientific claims all verified: CDG-2 located in Perseus cluster ~300 million light-years away ✓, ~99% dark matter ✓, first galaxy detected solely through its globular cluster population ✓, 4 confirmed globular clusters vs. Milky Way's 150+ ✓, GCs account for ~16% of visible content ✓, gravitational stripping explanation ✓, David Li at University of Toronto ✓. Minor discrepancy noted: the article states 'total luminosity equivalent to roughly one million Sun-like stars' but NASA Science and ScienceDaily both give the figure as ~6 million Sun-like stars; the ESA Hubble release says 'visible starlight equals roughly 1 million Suns' which likely refers to the non-cluster stellar background, not total luminosity. The discrepancy is minor and does not affect the scientific narrative or the article's conclusions.
